title: 2¬† Level 1 ‚Äì The Temple of Smriti (Memory)
section: 2.1 First Steps: Repeated Integration and the Cauchy Formula
text:
2.1 First Steps: Repeated Integration and the Cauchy Formula
Ananya: Acharya, this place feels mysterious. What lies in this temple?
Acharya Anvaya: This is the Temple of Smriti, or memory. It contains the secrets of memory, the key to which lies in the idea of the fractional integral.
Ananya: Hmm‚Ä¶ the integral is by itself a sort of memory, isn‚Äôt it? When we integrate a function from \(0\) to \(t\):
\[
I^1 f(t) = \int_{0}^{t} f(\tau)\, d\tau
\]
we are collecting its entire past. This is a kind of memory, isn‚Äôt it?
Acharya Anvaya: You are absolutely right, Ananya! But before the temple reveals its secret, let us recall what happens when we integrate repeatedly.
Question: What is the integral of \(1\)?
Ananya:
\[
I^1(1)(t) = \int_0^t 1\, d\tau = t.
\]
Acharya Anvaya: Good. And integrating once more?
Ananya:
\[
I^2(1)(t) = \int_0^t I^1(1)(\tau)\, d\tau = \int_0^t \tau\, d\tau = \frac{t^2}{2!}.
\]
Acharya Anvaya: And once more?
Ananya:
\[
I^3(1)(t) = \int_0^t I^2(1)(\tau)\, d\tau = \int_0^t \frac{\tau^2}{2}\, d\tau = \frac{t^3}{3!}.
\]
Acharya Anvaya: Yes! And we can find the \(n^{th}\) integral of a function \(f(x)\) using the Cauchy formula for repeated integration.

Cauchy formula for repeated integration
\[
I^n f(t) = \frac{1}{(n-1)!}\int_0^t (t-\tau)^{\,n-1} f(\tau)\, d\tau.
\]
crumbs: 2¬† Level 1 ‚Äì The Temple of Smriti (Memory)

title: 2¬† Level 1 ‚Äì The Temple of Smriti (Memory)
text:
2.2 The Riemann‚ÄìLiouville Integral
The temple wall shimmers again, and new verses appear, written in flowing Sanskrit:
‚Äú‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á, ‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡§§‡§•‡•à‡§µ ‡§Ö‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§É ‚Äî As memory gathers step by step, it stretches into infinity.‚Äù
Acharya Anvaya: The formula you just derived for integer \(n\), Ananya, is not bound to whole numbers alone. The Great ones in modern times, Riemann from Germany and Liouville from France extended it further. This is known today as the Riemann‚ÄìLiouville fractional integral:

Riemann‚ÄìLiouville fractional integral
\[
(I^\alpha f)(t) = \frac{1}{\Gamma(\alpha)} \int_0^t (t-\tau)^{\alpha-1} f(\tau)\, d\tau, \qquad \alpha > 0.
\]

Ananya: So it is the same as the Cauchy formula, but with \((n-1)!\) replaced by \(\Gamma(\alpha)\) ‚Äî allowing \(\alpha\) to be any positive real number?
Acharya Anvaya: Exactly. This was the leap ‚Äî from repeated integer steps to a smooth continuum of memory depths. Each value of \(\alpha\) encodes how strongly the past is remembered.
Acharya Anvaya: Just as the smriti texts preserve memory across centuries, a fractional integral preserves traces of all past values of a function. But the weight of remembrance fades, just as stories fade with time.
Ananya: So the past influences the present, but the farther back in time we go, the weaker its pull?
Acharya Anvaya: Precisely. Like the echo of a conch in the Himalayas ‚Äî recent notes ring loud, but the first strike still whispers faintly.


2.2.1 Mini-Quest 1: The Half-Memory

Evaluate \(I^{1/2}(1)\).
Answer:
\[
(I^{1/2}1)(t) = \frac{2}{\sqrt{\pi}}\, t^{1/2}.
\]

Acharya Anvaya: Well done, Ananya. You have grasped the essence of fractional memory. You now hold the Key of Smriti (Memory). With it, the temple doors open to the next journey.
The fractional integral is like oral tradition: newer retellings weigh more, but the first telling is never fully erased.
A smaller \(\alpha\) preserves distant past more strongly ‚Äî like stories handed down for centuries.
A larger \(\alpha\) emphasizes the near past ‚Äî like yesterday‚Äôs lived experiences.



2.2.2 Mini-Quest 2: Comparing Memories

Which value of \(\alpha\) remembers the distant past most strongly?

Choice A: \(\alpha = 0.2\)

Choice B: \(\alpha = 0.5\)

Choice C: \(\alpha = 0.9\)

Answer: Since the kernel is \((t-\tau)^{\alpha - 1}\), smaller \(\alpha\) means slower decay. So the answer is A.

Ananya: But where do we see such memory in materials?
crumbs: 2¬† Level 1 ‚Äì The Temple of Smriti (Memory)

title: 2¬† Level 1 ‚Äì The Temple of Smriti (Memory)
text:
2.3 Example: Stress‚ÄìStrain in Viscoelastic Fluids
Acharya Anvaya: Have you heard of Hooke‚Äôs law in solids?
Ananya: Yes! It says:
\[
\sigma(t) = E \, \varepsilon(t).
\]
The stress responds instantly to strain.
Acharya Anvaya: But how does this change for flowing materials?
Ananya: From what I know, for purely viscous fluids, Newton‚Äôs law governs:
\[
\sigma(t) = \eta \, \frac{d\varepsilon}{dt}(t).
\]
Acharya Anvaya: Here stress depends only on the rate of strain at the present moment.
Ananya: So both Hooke‚Äôs law and Newton‚Äôs law speak only of the present. They have no memory of what came before?
Acharya Anvaya: Exactly. But the world of polymers is different. These are viscoelastic materials. Their stress at time \(t\) remembers the entire history of strain. It is written as:

\[
\sigma(t) = \int_0^t G(t-\tau)\,\frac{d\varepsilon}{d\tau}(\tau)\,d\tau,
\]
where \(G\) is the relaxation kernel ‚Äî the weight of memory.

Ananya: So the kernel is like the echoing chamber of the temple ‚Äî weighing the voices of the past according to distance in time?
Acharya Anvaya: Precisely. If \(G\) is exponential we get Maxwell-type models. Experiments often show a power-law:

\[
G(t-\tau)\sim (t-\tau)^{-\alpha}, \qquad 0<\alpha<1.
\]

Ananya: Then stress never completely forgets ‚Äî the echoes fade slowly.
Acharya Anvaya: Substituting this kernel gives a fractional constitutive law:

\[
\sigma(t)=\eta_\alpha\,D_t^\alpha\varepsilon(t),
\]
where \(D_t^\alpha\) is a fractional derivative of the strain.


Ananya: Oh! But what exactly is a fractional derivative? I have never seen that symbol before!
Acharya Anvaya: For guidance:

For \(\alpha = 1\):
\[
D_t^1 \varepsilon(t) = \frac{d\varepsilon}{dt}(t),
\]
the ordinary derivative, as in Newton‚Äôs law of viscosity.
For \(\alpha = 0\):
\[
D_t^0 \varepsilon(t) = \varepsilon(t),
\]
i.e.¬†the function itself, as in Hooke‚Äôs law of elasticity.
For \(0<\alpha<1\):
\(D_t^\alpha\) interpolates smoothly between these two extremes, capturing behavior that is partly elastic and partly viscous (viscoelastic behavior).


Ananya: So when \(\alpha=0\), the memory is eternal ‚Äî purely elastic. When \(\alpha=1\), memory vanishes quickly ‚Äî purely viscous. And for \(0<\alpha<1\), we have viscoelasticity, with fading memory that bridges the two.
Acharya Anvaya: Exactly! Thus, the language of fractional calculus is the scripture that describes memory in matter ‚Äî echoing from the temple walls into the world of flowing polymers.
Acharya Anvaya: We will learn about fractional derivatives as we go further to the The River of Derivatives.

Narrator: With the Key of Smriti in hand, Ananya steps through the temple gates. The path ahead leads to the River of Derivatives.

title: 3¬† Level 2 ‚Äì The River of Derivatives
text:
3.0.1 Scene: Arrival at the River
Characters:
- Acharya Anvaya (Guide/Teacher, continuity of knowledge)
- Ananya (Learner, seeker of truth)
With the Key of Smriti in hand, Ananya steps beyond the temple gates. A wide river flows before her, restless and shining. On the shore rest two boats, each with a carved name: Riemann‚ÄìLiouville and Caputo.
Ananya: Two boats? Which one do we take to cross the River of Derivatives?
Acharya Anvaya: Both will carry you across, but their way of remembering the river differs. One boat remembers everything since the river‚Äôs source üåä; the other begins its memory only when you step aboard üö§ ‚Äî that is, when you set your initial conditions.
crumbs: 3¬† Level 2 ‚Äì The River of Derivatives

title: 3¬† Level 2 ‚Äì The River of Derivatives
text:
3.1 Rigorous Definitions
Acharya Anvaya: Let us be precise. Suppose \(n-1 < \alpha \leq n\) with \(n \in \mathbb{N}\).

Riemann‚ÄìLiouville fractional derivative
\[
D_t^\alpha f(t) = \frac{d^n}{dt^n}\, I^{\,n-\alpha} f(t)
= \frac{1}{\Gamma(n-\alpha)}\frac{d^n}{dt^n}\int_0^t (t-\tau)^{\,n-\alpha-1} f(\tau)\,d\tau.
\]


Caputo fractional derivative
\[
{}^C D_t^\alpha f(t) =
I^{\,n-\alpha} f^{(n)}(t)
= \frac{1}{\Gamma(n-\alpha)}\int_0^t (t-\tau)^{\,n-\alpha-1} f^{(n)}(\tau)\,d\tau.
\]

Ananya: So the difference is: Riemann‚ÄìLiouville differentiates after integrating, while Caputo differentiates before integrating?
Acharya Anvaya: Exactly. Two boats across the same river ‚Äî same waters, different journeys üòá.
crumbs: 3¬† Level 2 ‚Äì The River of Derivatives

title: 3¬† Level 2 ‚Äì The River of Derivatives
text:

title: 3¬† Level 2 ‚Äì The River of Derivatives
text:
3.3 Worked Example: Power Functions

For the Riemann‚ÄìLiouville derivative of \(t^\beta\) (\(\beta > -1\)):
\[
D_t^\alpha \, t^\beta = \frac{\Gamma(\beta+1)}{\Gamma(\beta-\alpha+1)} \, t^{\beta-\alpha}.
\]

Example: with \(\alpha = \tfrac{1}{2}\) and \(f(t)=t^2\):
\[
D_t^{1/2}\, t^2 = \frac{\Gamma(3)}{\Gamma(2.5)} \, t^{3/2}.
\]
crumbs: 3¬† Level 2 ‚Äì The River of Derivatives

title: 3¬† Level 2 ‚Äì The River of Derivatives
section: 3.4 Worked Example: Caputo Derivative of Power Functions
text:
3.4 Worked Example: Caputo Derivative of Power Functions


If \(f(t) = t^\beta\) with \(\beta \leq n-1\), then \({}^C D_t^\alpha f(t) = 0\).

If \(\beta > n-1\), then

\[
{}^C D_t^\alpha t^\beta
= \frac{\Gamma(\beta+1)}{\Gamma(\beta-\alpha+1)}\, t^{\beta-\alpha}.
\]

So for most powers, Riemann‚ÄìLiouville and Caputo agree, but for low-degree polynomials, Caputo derivatives vanish.


3.4.1 Mini-Quest: Compare RL and Caputo

Task: Compute the Riemann‚ÄìLiouville and Caputo derivatives of \(f(t)=t^2\) for \(\alpha = \tfrac12\).

Riemann‚ÄìLiouville:
\[
D_t^{1/2} t^2 = \frac{\Gamma(3)}{\Gamma(2.5)}\, t^{3/2}.
\]
Caputo:
\[
{}^C D_t^{1/2} t^2 = \frac{\Gamma(3)}{\Gamma(2.5)}\, t^{3/2}.
\]

Observation: For this function, both definitions give the same result.
crumbs: 3¬† Level 2 ‚Äì The River of Derivatives

title: 3¬† Level 2 ‚Äì The River of Derivatives
text:
3.5 Worked Example: Exponentials

For exponentials:
\[
D_t^\alpha e^{\lambda t} = {}^C D_t^\alpha e^{\lambda t} = \lambda^\alpha e^{\lambda t}.
\]

Ananya: Beautiful! The exponential remains its own shape, and \(\lambda\) is lifted to a fractional power.
Acharya Anvaya: Exactly. Exponentials are the eigenfunctions of fractional derivatives. Ananya: üòá
crumbs: 3¬† Level 2 ‚Äì The River of Derivatives

title: 3¬† Level 2 ‚Äì The River of Derivatives
text:
3.6 Rules of the River (Caputo Properties)

Rule 1. Linearity
For constants \(c_1, c_2\) and functions \(f, g\):
\[
{}^C D_t^\alpha (c_1 f(t) + c_2 g(t))
= c_1 \, {}^C D_t^\alpha f(t) + c_2 \, {}^C D_t^\alpha g(t).
\]


Rule 2. Constants and Polynomials

For a constant \(C\), \({}^C D_t^\alpha C = 0\).

For \(t^\beta\) with \(\beta = 0,1,\dots,n-1\), \({}^C D_t^\alpha t^\beta = 0\).

For \(\beta > n-1\),
\[
{}^C D_t^\alpha t^\beta = \frac{\Gamma(\beta+1)}{\Gamma(\beta-\alpha+1)}\, t^{\beta-\alpha}.
\]



Rule 3. Exponentials and Trigonometric Functions

\({}^C D_t^\alpha e^{\lambda t} = \lambda^\alpha e^{\lambda t}\).

\({}^C D_t^\alpha \sin(\omega t) = \omega^\alpha \sin\!\left(\omega t + \tfrac{\pi\alpha}{2}\right)\).

\({}^C D_t^\alpha \cos(\omega t) = \omega^\alpha \cos\!\left(\omega t + \tfrac{\pi\alpha}{2}\right)\).



Rule 4. Product and Chain Rules (Caution!)
Unlike classical derivatives, Caputo derivatives do not have simple product or chain rules. Use linearity safely, but treat products/compositions with care.
crumbs: 3¬† Level 2 ‚Äì The River of Derivatives

title: 3¬† Level 2 ‚Äì The River of Derivatives
text:
3.7 Mini-Exercises: Rules of the River

Exercise 1. Constant function
Compute \({}^C D_t^{1/2} (5)\).
Answer: \(0\).


Exercise 2. Power function
Compute \({}^C D_t^{1/2} (t^3)\).
Answer: \(\dfrac{\Gamma(4)}{\Gamma(3.5)} \, t^{2.5}\).


Exercise 3. Exponential
Compute \({}^C D_t^{1/2} (e^{2t})\).
Answer: \(\sqrt{2}\, e^{2t}\).


Exercise 4. Trigonometric
Compute \({}^C D_t^{1/2} (\sin t)\).
Answer: \(\sin\!\left(t + \tfrac{\pi}{4}\right)\).


Exercise 5. RL vs Caputo
Show that for \(f(t)=t\):
- \({}^C D_t^{1/2}(t) = 0\),
- \(D_t^{1/2}(t) = \dfrac{\Gamma(2)}{\Gamma(1.5)}\, t^{0.5}\).

title: 4¬† Level 2.5 ‚Äì The Grove of Expansions
text:
4.0.1 Scene: The Grove of Expansions
Characters:
- Acharya Anvaya (Guide/Teacher, continuity of knowledge)
- Ananya (Learner, seeker of truth)
Ananya and Acharya leave the boats behind and walk into a quiet grove of trees. The branches seem to stretch infinitely, each sprouting smaller and smaller twigs.
Ananya: These trees look endless, Acharya. Each branch divides into more branches, and so on forever.
Acharya Anvaya: Exactly, Ananya. Just as trees expand endlessly, so too can a function expand in terms of its derivatives. You know this in ordinary calculus as the Taylor expansion.
Ananya: Yes, where a function \(f(t)\) is expressed as an infinite sum involving its derivatives at \(t=0\).
crumbs: 4¬† Level 2.5 ‚Äì The Grove of Expansions

title: 4¬† Level 2.5 ‚Äì The Grove of Expansions
section: 4.1 From Classical to Fractional Taylor Expansion
text:
4.1 From Classical to Fractional Taylor Expansion

Classical Taylor formula (order \(m\)):
\[
f(t) = \sum_{k=0}^{m-1} \frac{f^{(k)}(0)}{k!}\, t^k \;+\; R_m(t),
\]
with remainder
\[
R_m(t) = \frac{1}{(m-1)!} \int_0^t (t-\tau)^{m-1} f^{(m)}(\tau)\, d\tau.
\]

Acharya Anvaya: Now, in the language of memory, we can generalize this formula. Instead of the \(m\)-th derivative, we allow a fractional order \(\alpha\).

Fractional Taylor formula (Caputo)
For \(m-1 < \alpha \le m\),
\[
f(t) = \sum_{k=0}^{m-1} \frac{f^{(k)}(0)}{k!}\, t^k
\;+\; \frac{1}{\Gamma(\alpha)} \int_0^t (t-\tau)^{\alpha-1}\, {}^C D_t^\alpha f(\tau)\, d\tau.
\]

Ananya: So the beginning looks like the classical expansion, but the remainder now contains a fractional derivative instead of an integer one.
Acharya Anvaya: Precisely. The forest of expansions stretches into the fractional realm üåø. The remainder term is a memory integral, showing how past values influence the approximation.
crumbs: 4¬† Level 2.5 ‚Äì The Grove of Expansions

title: 4¬† Level 2.5 ‚Äì The Grove of Expansions
text:
4.2 Example: Exponential Function
Ananya: Can we try this with a familiar function, like \(f(t)=e^t\)?
Acharya Anvaya: Of course. Note that \(f^{(k)}(0)=1\) for all \(k\).

For \(m=1\), \(\alpha \in (0,1]\), the expansion is:
\[
e^t = 1 \;+\; \frac{1}{\Gamma(\alpha)} \int_0^t (t-\tau)^{\alpha-1}\, {}^C D_t^\alpha e^\tau\, d\tau.
\]
But \({}^C D_t^\alpha e^\tau = 1^\alpha e^\tau = e^\tau\),
so the remainder is
\[
\frac{1}{\Gamma(\alpha)} \int_0^t (t-\tau)^{\alpha-1} e^\tau\, d\tau.
\]

Ananya: That integral looks like a weighted memory of the exponential.
Acharya Anvaya: Exactly. For \(\alpha=1\), it reduces to the ordinary Taylor remainder.
crumbs: 4¬† Level 2.5 ‚Äì The Grove of Expansions

title: 4¬† Level 2.5 ‚Äì The Grove of Expansions
text:
4.3 Mini-Exercises: Grove Practice

Exercise 1. Constant function
Show that the fractional Taylor formula for \(f(t)=1\) reduces to \(f(t)=1\) with zero remainder.


Exercise 2. Linear function
Apply the fractional Taylor formula to \(f(t)=t\).
Hint: Remember \({}^C D_t^\alpha (t)=0\) for \(0<\alpha\le1\).


Exercise 3. Exponential comparison
Compute the first two classical Taylor terms for \(e^t\) and compare with the fractional expansion remainder when \(\alpha=1/2\).



Narrator: Among the trees of the grove, Ananya learns how expansions can carry memory into infinite branches. With this tool in hand, she steps onward, ready to face the Forest of Equations, where entire systems of fractional order await.

title: 5¬† Palace of Eternal Exponentials
text:
6 Palace of Eternal Exponentials
A new level in the journey: follow the marble walkway from the Grove of Expansions and enter the Palace of Eternal Exponentials, where echoes stretch and memory lives in the walls. This page mixes mythic scenes, dialogues (Ananya & Acharya Anvay), mathematics, runnable code, and student quests ‚Äî all ready to drop into your Quarto project.
crumbs: 5¬† Palace of Eternal Exponentials

title: 5¬† Palace of Eternal Exponentials
text:
6.1 Scene 1 ‚Äî Entrance & lore
The palace gates open on a fresco of two names: Mittag and Leffler. A gentle wind seems to replay the earliest footsteps ‚Äî not as an exponential fade but as a long remembered murmur. Ananya and Acharya Anvay stand beneath the arch.
Ananya: ‚ÄúWhy does this place feel like it remembers everything?‚Äù
Acharya Anvay: ‚ÄúBecause its laws are fractional ‚Äî the halls do not forget the past at once. Here, the exponential is a resident, but the palace sings a deeper song.‚Äù


Short classroom prompt

Ask students: ‚ÄúCompare the intuition behind exponential decay \(e^{-t}\) and the Mittag‚ÄìLeffler decay for \(E_{\alpha}(-t^{\alpha})\). What physical processes might each model better?‚Äù
crumbs: 5¬† Palace of Eternal Exponentials

title: 5¬† Palace of Eternal Exponentials
section: 6.2 Scene 2 ‚Äî Grand Hall: definitions & quick facts
text:
6.2 Scene 2 ‚Äî Grand Hall: definitions & quick facts
The Grand Hall contains a carved plaque with the incantation.
\(E_{\alpha,\beta}(z) = \sum_{k=0}^{\infty} \frac{z^k}{\Gamma(\alpha k + \beta)}, \qquad \alpha>0,\ \beta\in\mathbb C.\)
The single-parameter function is \(E_{\alpha}(z)=E_{\alpha,1}(z)\). A small doorway labeled \(\alpha=1\) leads back to a chamber inscribed with \(e^z\).


Properties & remarks


Entire function: the series converges for all \(z\in\mathbb C\).
Special case: \(E_{1,1}(z)=e^z\) because \(\Gamma(k+1)=k!\).
Memory: for \(0<\alpha<1\) solutions often decay algebraically rather than exponentially, giving long tails.
crumbs: 5¬† Palace of Eternal Exponentials

title: 5¬† Palace of Eternal Exponentials
text:
6.3 Scene 3 ‚Äî Library of Laplace transforms (derivation)
They enter a quiet library where scrolls record transform pairs. Acharya Anvay unrolls a scroll.
Acharya Anvay: ‚ÄúTake the Caputo equation \({}^{C}D_t^\alpha y = \lambda y,\quad y(0)=y_0\), with \(0<\alpha\le 1\).‚Äù
Ananya: ‚ÄúLaplace it ‚Äî as if we seek the frequency-soul of the equation.‚Äù
Using the Caputo Laplace identity,
\(\mathcal L\{ {}^{C}D_t^\alpha y\}(s) = s^\alpha \tilde y(s) - s^{\alpha-1} y(0),\)
we obtain
\(s^\alpha \tilde y(s) - s^{\alpha-1} y_0 = \lambda \tilde y(s) \quad\Rightarrow\quad \tilde y(s) = \frac{s^{\alpha-1} y_0}{s^\alpha - \lambda}.\)
Inverting with the standard Laplace pair (see below) yields
\(y(t) = y_0 E_\alpha(\lambda t^\alpha).\)


Laplace pair used (reminder)

For suitable \(s\) and real \(\beta\),
\(\mathcal L\{ t^{\beta-1} E_{\alpha,\beta}(\pm \lambda t^\alpha)\}(s) = \frac{s^{\alpha-\beta}}{s^\alpha \mp \lambda}.\)
Setting \(\beta=1\) recovers the pair used in the derivation.
crumbs: 5¬† Palace of Eternal Exponentials

title: 5¬† Palace of Eternal Exponentials
text:
6.4 Scene 4 ‚Äî Mirror Room: asymptotics & intuition
The Mirror Room bends long reflections into slow tails. A descriptive dialogue helps students internalize asymptotics.
Ananya: ‚ÄúWhen alpha is small, why do echoes die so slowly?‚Äù
Acharya Anvay: ‚ÄúBecause the Mittag‚ÄìLeffler‚Äôs coefficients, divided by Gamma(\(\alpha k+1\)), shift more mass to early terms and produce algebraic-like behaviour at long times ‚Äî the memory stores the past.‚Äù


Concise asymptotic note (for teacher)

For \(0<\alpha<2\) and large \(|z|\) away from certain sectorial rays, there are known asymptotic expansions of \(E_{\alpha,\beta}(z)\). On the negative real axis, solutions like \(E_\alpha(-t^\alpha)\) typically show slower decay than \(e^{-t}\), often algebraic in nature; reference Mainardi (2000) for readable summaries.
crumbs: 5¬† Palace of Eternal Exponentials

title: 5¬† Palace of Eternal Exponentials
text:
6.5 Scene 5 ‚Äî Marble Hall: mini-quest (numerical verification)
The Marble Hall contains a bench where students can perform three trials.
Mini-Quest

Verify numerically that the Caputo ODE

\({}^{C}D_t^\alpha y(t) = -y(t), \quad y(0)=1,\)
has solution \(y(t)=E_\alpha(-t^\alpha)\) for \(\alpha=0.6\) on \([0,5]\).

Prove \(E_1(z)=e^z\) by comparing series.
Bonus: estimate time \(T\) where \(E_{0.6}(-t^{0.6})<0.1\) and compare with exponential decay.



Starter hint (GL scheme)

Use the Gr√ºnwald‚ÄìLetnikov approximation for the fractional derivative with step \(\Delta t\):
\({}^{C}D_t^\alpha y(t_n) \approx \frac{1}{(\Delta t)^\alpha} \sum_{k=0}^n w_k y_{n-k},\)
where \(w_k = (-1)^k \binom{\alpha}{k}\). March forward in time and compare to \(E_\alpha(-t^\alpha)\) from mpmath.
